intro: Haplopappus bloomeri var. ophitidis, commonly known as the Ophitid's Haplopappus, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its foliage consists of narrow, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, aiding in water retention. The flowers, which bloom in the summer, are yellow and arranged in compact clusters, contributing to its ornamental value in native plant gardens.
